image.altText: Four men in handcuffs stand with sheriff's officers outside a yellow brick building

items.synopsis: The underworld connections of one of the four men responsible for a fatal bashing in an Adelaide school car park three years ago can be revealed for the first time, after a South Australian judge allowed a suppression to be lifted.

title.children: School car park killer revealed as son of bikie executed on Gold Coast

image.altText: Pauline Hanson, dressed in a red jacket, wears a serious expression as she walks out of the Senate.

items.synopsis: A misleading viral video shared by One Nation leader Pauline Hanson and anti-Voice campaigners has sparked a wave of racial abuse towards an Aboriginal family and has left another couple feeling "crucified".

title.children: Families distressed after 'highly misleading' video used by anti-Voice campaigners goes viral

image.altText: Tayla Cox wears pink and holds her baby girl Murphy

items.synopsis: Matthew Cox has been charged with murder after police found the bodies of his wife and baby girl.

title.children: Parents of Queensland man accused of killing his wife and 11-week-old daughter in 'state of shock'

image.altText: A close up image of an engineered bacteria.

items.synopsis: The engineered bacteria called Acinetobacter baylyi has the ability to search through an environment, like the colon, and detect cancer DNA. Researchers say it could be used to screen for bowel cancer in a blood test.

title.children: Australian researchers engineer bacteria that could detect bowel cancer without stool test

image.altText: a woman with a scarf standing in front of a colourful wall mural

items.synopsis: An Adelaide hospital is supporting students admitted to its mental health ward to keep on top of their education under a new program that has attracted global interest.

title.children: Annie's daughter was 'disengaged', but a hospital program has inspired her to consider teaching

image.altText: An aerial photo of a large deep blue lake surrounded by a ring road and adjoining farm properties.

items.synopsis: Locals say they avoid a walking path around Blue Lake in Mount Gambier, but a concept to improve pedestrian safety has split local opinion.

title.children: Tourists love this crater lake — but many locals avoid it. Could a radical change improve safety for everyone?

image.altText: The Bushwalkers artwork showing a group of people outside.

items.synopsis: Southern Highlands baker Tracy Nickl was clearing out artwork from his grandfather's home when he nearly gave one worth more than a million dollars to an op shop until his friend, artist Ben Quilty, saw it.

title.children: Million-dollar painting that nearly ended up in op shop now bound for National Gallery

image.altText: Sportswomen in pale blue uniforms celebrate.

items.synopsis: Spain beats Netherlands 2-1 after extra time to reach a first-ever FIFA Women's World Cup semifinal. Later, heavyweights Japan and Sweden meet at Eden Park in Auckland. Follow live.

title.children: We look ahead to the Matildas' clash with France. If Kerr starts, who do you drop?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If Sam Kerr is fit to play 90 minutes, she will start against France. Matildas coach Tony Gustavsson cut to the chase when asked about the role Australia's superstar captain would play in Saturday's Women's World Cup quarterfinal. Kerr has played a tick over 10 minutes against Denmark to date, with a starting front four of Caitlin Foord, Mary Fowler, Emily van Egmond and Hayley Raso thriving in her absence. But Gustavsson dismissed the suggestion dropping someone for Kerr, if she is fit to start after returning from her calf injury, could disrupt that dynamic. "They've been amazing teammates supporting each other. There's been no complaints whatsoever in terms of if you start or come off the bench - they know their role and they play their role," Gustavsson said. "And I definitely would never, ever see Sam as a disturbance to the team. "I want to be very clear in here now to say if Sam is fit to play 90 minutes, she is starting. There is not even a question and the team knows it. "We're talking about Sam Kerr here. "Whether she is ready to play 90 minutes plus extra time, that's to be decided tonight. But there is no question whatsoever that if she is, she is starting." -AAP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We're talking about Sam Kerr here': Gustavsson says Kerr will start - if fit enough

children.content: (Getty Images)
If Sam Kerr is fit to play 90 minutes, she will start against France.
Matildas coach Tony Gustavsson cut to the chase when asked about the role Australia's superstar captain would play in Saturday's Women's World Cup quarterfinal.
Kerr has played a tick over 10 minutes against Denmark to date, with a starting front four of Caitlin Foord, Mary Fowler, Emily van Egmond and Hayley Raso thriving in her absence.
But Gustavsson dismissed the suggestion dropping someone for Kerr, if she is fit to start after returning from her calf injury, could disrupt that dynamic.
(Getty Images)

"They've been amazing teammates supporting each other. There's been no complaints whatsoever in terms of if you start or come off the bench - they know their role and they play their role," Gustavsson said.
"And I definitely would never, ever see Sam as a disturbance to the team.
"I want to be very clear in here now to say if Sam is fit to play 90 minutes, she is starting. There is not even a question and the team knows it.
"We're talking about Sam Kerr here.
"Whether she is ready to play 90 minutes plus extra time, that's to be decided tonight. But there is no question whatsoever that if she is, she is starting."
-AAP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: How are we feeling ahead of tomorrow's game? France are an experienced side with plenty of hunger - remember they've never won an international competition either. They have a decent defence and lots of attacking talent. That being said, the Matildas have played very well in their last two games, and will have Kerr at their disposal - either as a sub or from the start. To me it's a 50-50 game, but Australia have a slight edge due to home advantage. Lang Park should be pumping. What do you think?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Let's talk Matildas

children.content: (Getty)
How are we feeling ahead of tomorrow's game?
France are an experienced side with plenty of hunger - remember they've never won an international competition either.
They have a decent defence and lots of attacking talent.
That being said, the Matildas have played very well in their last two games, and will have Kerr at their disposal - either as a sub or from the start.
To me it's a 50-50 game, but Australia have a slight edge due to home advantage. Lang Park should be pumping.
What do you think?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Spain are into the semifinals! And they have a new hero, their youngest ever World Cup goalscorer, Salma Paralluelo. Well, Spain deserved that on the balance of play, but the Netherlands did not make it easy for them. Aside from the penalty in the second half of normal time, they struggled to find a way through despite dominating possession. That is until Hermoso and Paralluelo combined for a delightful winner. The 2019 finalists are out, and Spain are into the final four for the first time ever.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FULL-TIME: Spain 2 -1 Netherlands

children.content: (Getty)
Spain are into the semifinals!
And they have a new hero, their youngest ever World Cup goalscorer, Salma Paralluelo.
Well, Spain deserved that on the balance of play, but the Netherlands did not make it easy for them.
Aside from the penalty in the second half of normal time, they struggled to find a way through despite dominating possession.
That is until Hermoso and Paralluelo combined for a delightful winner.
The 2019 finalists are out, and Spain are into the final four for the first time ever.

image.altText: A young, smiling blonde woman in a garden.

items.synopsis: Italian tourist Victoria Cafasso had been in Tasmania barely a week in 1995 when she was stabbed 17 times on an idyllic beach in broad daylight. Twenty-seven years on, police release new images and reveal they have conducted recent searches.

title.children: Police conducting new searches over grisly unsolved beach murder of Italian tourist Victoria Cafasso

image.altText: A man sits on a rock

items.synopsis: A coroner has stopped parents of Luke Gilbert from giving their family impact statement after they refused to edit sections deemed "factually incorrect and offensive" by police.

title.children: Police shooting victim's swastika tattoos analysed as parents barred from making 'offensive' impact statement

image.altText: Ed Sheeran points at Michael Gudinski who hugs him and points a finger up. They wear matching black t shirts

items.synopsis: The star-studded Ego: The Michael Gudinski Story is loud, brash, and irreverent - just like the Mushroom mogul himself.

title.children: The Michael Gudinski doco is an irreverent portrait of the man who made the Australian music industry

image.altText: A large, khaki-green military vehicle on treads, sits stationary on a slab of concrete. It is surrounded by machine parts.

items.synopsis: Wodonga resident Darrin Wright's dad found the Bren Gun Carrier in a paddock in the 1980s. Now it is mostly restored and its owners want to see it go to a good home.

title.children: Armoured carrier from WWII listed for sale on Facebook Marketplace

image.altText: Emma Walters appears serious as she walks out of the Melbourne Magistrates' Court.

items.synopsis: Emma Walters had been charged with plotting to kill her former partner John Setka, but police have now dropped those and other serious charges. She still faces other charges.

title.children: Police drop serious charges against Emma Walters, wife of union boss John Setka

image.altText: Two women and a man wearing black flying suits hugging each other and smiling

items.synopsis: Virgin Galactic flew its commercial flight carrying tourists for the first time and reached 88 kilometres above Earth.

title.children: Caribbean mother-daughter duo and 80-year-old Olympian taken to the edge of space

image.altText: A waitress in a white shirt carries a tray of glasses in a Canberra restaurant.

items.synopsis: To deal with the rising cost of living, there's nearly 194,000 young people juggling side hustles — the highest it's ever been — with some saying it's "unavoidable".

title.children: 'Young people are hustlers': Gen Z 'willing to do what they need to' to make ends meet

image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe has faced the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time. Meanwhile, US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: RBA boss says it's 'too early to declare victory' against inflation but 'the worst is over'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The UK economy has grew by 0.5% in June — higher than economists had expected — according to the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics. The data also showed the economy grew 0.2% in the second quarter — the best growth its seen in over a year. The ONS said the reason for the growth in June came was partly because of the extra Bank Holiday in May for the King's coronation, while warm weather saw increased activity at pubs and restaurants, as well as the construction sector.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UK economy grows by more than expected in June thanks to coronation, warm weather

children.content: The UK economy has grew by 0.5% in June — higher than economists had expected — according to the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics.
The data also showed the economy grew 0.2% in the second quarter — the best growth its seen in over a year.

The ONS said the reason for the growth in June came was partly because of the extra Bank Holiday in May for the King's coronation, while warm weather saw increased activity at pubs and restaurants, as well as the construction sector.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With just under 40 minutes of the trading week left, the ASX is continuing to edge lower as a result of miners and resources. Energy and basic materials are the worst performing sectors, down 1.9% and 0.9% respectively. Industrials and tech stocks have also shed 0.8% and 0.6%, but there has been positive movement for consumer cyclicals (up 0.7%), academic services and healthcare (+0.3% each) and real estate picking up 0.2%. The top performer is far and away Star Entertainment Group, thanks to the NSW government's changing tax regime guaranteeing thousands of jobs until 2030. Here's the top five best movers as we approach the end of the session: Star Entertainment Group +18.5% Syrah Resources +8.7% AMP +7.4% Boral +4.5% Bellevue Gold +4.55 At the other end, it's red for resources and miners: Lake Resources -7.1% New Hope Corporation -3.8% BlueScope Steel -3.4% Beach Energy -3.1% Whitehaven Coal -3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX continues to edge lower as session end approaches

children.content: With just under 40 minutes of the trading week left, the ASX is continuing to edge lower as a result of miners and resources.
Energy and basic materials are the worst performing sectors, down 1.9% and 0.9% respectively.

Industrials and tech stocks have also shed 0.8% and 0.6%, but there has been positive movement for consumer cyclicals (up 0.7%), academic services and healthcare (+0.3% each) and real estate picking up 0.2%.
The top performer is far and away Star Entertainment Group, thanks to the NSW government's changing tax regime guaranteeing thousands of jobs until 2030.
Here's the top five best movers as we approach the end of the session:
Star Entertainment Group +18.5%
Syrah Resources +8.7%
Boral +4.5%
Bellevue Gold +4.55
At the other end, it's red for resources and miners:
Lake Resources -7.1%
New Hope Corporation -3.8%
BlueScope Steel -3.4%
Beach Energy -3.1%
Whitehaven Coal -3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Philip Lowe was asked whether he had any thoughts about rent controls at the start of the hearing by committee chair Daniel Mulino. Mr Lowe replied by saying although they could provide short-term solutions to the problem, it would ultimately make the problem of a lack of affordable rentals worse. Here's his full response to that question: "When housing prices were rising quickly, people were saying, 'Well, we need to give people more money to help with them,' and when rents are rising quickly, 'We need to kind of cap the rent increases'. " They're short-term fixes that both of them, in my judgment, make the problem worse. "So what I would like to see is a longer-term focus on this because the short-term solutions, or the short-term responses, are not solutions, and generally giving people more money or capping prices doesn't help with the balance of supply and demand in the market. " In most cases, rent controls reduce incentive to add to supply, so it might help in the short run, it might relieve some pressure on people in the short run, and clearly that's the case, but we've got to keep the medium-term perspective on this. "Will that add to the supply of rental accommodation over time? My judgment would be that it would not and could actually reduce it. "It might help in the short run but create problems in the long run."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Would rent controls be an effective way to help manage with housing issues?

children.content: Philip Lowe was asked whether he had any thoughts about
rent controls
at the start of the hearing by committee chair Daniel Mulino.
Mr Lowe replied by saying although they could provide short-term solutions to the problem, it would ultimately make the problem of a lack of affordable rentals worse.
Here's his full response to that question:

"When housing prices were rising quickly, people were saying, 'Well, we need to give people more money to help with them,' and when rents are rising quickly, 'We need to kind of cap the rent increases'.
They're short-term fixes that both of them, in my judgment, make the problem worse
"So what I would like to see is a longer-term focus on this because the short-term solutions, or the short-term responses, are not solutions, and generally
giving people more money or capping prices doesn't help with the balance of supply and demand in the market
In most cases, rent controls reduce incentive to add to supply
, so it might help in the short run, it might relieve some pressure on people in the short run, and clearly that's the case, but we've got to keep the medium-term perspective on this.
"Will that add to the supply of rental accommodation over time?
My judgment would be that it would not and could actually reduce it.
"It might help in the short run but create problems in the long run."

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing a cap carrying an orange painting

items.synopsis: As Darwin launches one of Australia's biggest Indigenous art fairs, some artists fear allegations about interference in Indigenous paintings may have tarnished the industry's reputation and affected sales.

title.children: It's the biggest sales weekend for remote Aboriginal artists, but some fear their reputation has been tarnished

image.altText: An Asian woman standing behind a coffee machine.

items.synopsis: Cafes and restaurants saw a boom of big-spending customers after the pandemic. Now, as cost-of-living pressures bite households and the cost of doing business grows, some in the hospitality industry are struggling to stay afloat.

title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

title.children: How a drought, a heatwave and a hurricane created Hawaii's deadliest wildfires ever

image.altText: A man in a blue vest and blue shirt holds his hands in the air, at a rally

items.synopsis: Six Colombian men found hiding in a house in Quito are captured and arrested over the assassination of Ecuadorian presidential candidate Fernando Villavicencio.

title.children: Six Colombians arrested over assassination of Ecuadorian presidential candidate

title.children: CheckMate: Anthony Albanese says the Uluru Statement is one page, Jacinta Price says it's 26. Who is correct?
